text:
Welcome to How To Cook That, I'm Ann ReardonÂ 
and this is another episode of Cake Rescue,Â Â

where I take viral cake fails and show you how toÂ 
rescue them. Let's start with the toppling towersÂ Â

of some very tall cakes. Emmy's Kitchen hadÂ 
this one collapse in transit and she said sheÂ Â

just cried when she got there and saw it. ThisÂ 
cake went on a 45-minute journey successfullyÂ Â

before toppling over on a u-turn. Cakes by JeanÂ 
made a great batman cake that was badly damagedÂ Â

when the customer drove it home and Sweetie PieÂ 
Dublin made this beautiful cake for a customerÂ Â

and after it left the store it ended up lookingÂ 
like this! So first of all let's recreate theÂ Â

fail and then we'll talk about how to fix itÂ 
tall cakes that are being transported need twoÂ Â

types of support they need vertical support whichÂ 
is to support the weight of the cake from beingÂ Â

squashed by the other cakes that are stackedÂ 
up on top of it but they're also going to needÂ Â

support to stop them from toppling over and thatÂ 
is a different type of support for that you needÂ Â

something that's attached to the baseboard youÂ 
could use a metal rod secured with nuts underneathÂ Â

and on top if you have a wooden board and then theÂ 
center of the cake would have one of these tubesÂ Â

they just slot right over the top and if possibleÂ 
you transport the cake with the tiers separate andÂ Â

when you get to the venue you just slot the nextÂ 
tier on top and that rod makes sure it's a hundredÂ Â

percent central and it also stops it fallingÂ 
off in transit. You're also going to need aÂ Â

strong central support like this in top heavyÂ 
cakes like i showed you with the minion cakeÂ Â

the rocket cake my little pony anime watering canÂ 
cake caramel popcorn prince harry spiderman standÂ Â

mixer cake all of those are on the channel butÂ 
if you're just at home with a normal tall cakeÂ Â

and it's just going from the fridge to the tableÂ 
you don't need that really strong central supportÂ Â

these sort of supports would be ideal this is aÂ 
firm hollow plastic tube and this is just a woodenÂ Â

support or at a pinch you could use cake popÂ 
sticks but as soon as you need some side to sideÂ Â

support these are not going to be enough. So let'sÂ 
use these today because we want to make it failÂ Â

put a cake board on top and stack it up and thenÂ 
let's make another tier to go on top of the firstÂ Â

one make it even taller and stack that on top andÂ 
put it into a box in the car and off we go ...Â Â

so far so good, it only has that vertical supportÂ 
no horizontal support it's just come out of theÂ Â

fridge so that helps make it more secure becauseÂ 
the buttercream is quite firm but if you'reÂ Â

driving a long way you have to consider thatÂ 
buttercream is going to heat up. We're drivingÂ Â

on fairly flat roads here but I'm going toÂ 
ask Dave to turn into a sloped driveway...

Now you need to get your before and after shotÂ 
for Instagram and wipe away your tears and figureÂ Â

out how you're going to fix this damaged cake!Â 
The first thing you want to do is grab a plateÂ Â

and separate your tiers out and we'll deal withÂ 
each one separately and remember things like thisÂ Â

happen it's just cake and it's all going to beÂ 
okay ğŸ’• Now because the bottom layer has tippedÂ Â

over it's let the weight of the cake squash theÂ 
bottom bit of cake and even if we stand it upÂ Â

it won't stay standing for long because thatÂ 
bottom area is now squashed and crumbly andÂ Â

most probably the cake pop stick has probablyÂ 
slipped and is no longer supporting it.Â Â

So i suggest you add another cake pop stick or aÂ 
skewer or anything you have in the house that'sÂ Â

food safe to prop it up to the height of thatÂ 
cake board so that it won't fall over again.Â Â

Now to make them look good grab some foilÂ 
that's long enough to wrap around yourÂ Â

cake and fold it down so the top is slightlyÂ 
taller than the height of the first tierÂ Â

then flip it over and scrunch up the foil,Â 
don't do it so tight that you can't get itÂ Â

apart without ripping it, we just want to scrunchÂ 
it up and make sure it's crinkled everywhere.Â Â

Then use your hands to flatten it out again spreadÂ 
some melted compound chocolate over the foilÂ Â

now you can use real chocolate here ifÂ 
you know how to temper chocolate but thisÂ Â

is a rescue so I'm going for the fastestÂ 
easiest option and using compound chocolate.Â Â

Once it's evenly spread lift the foil and moveÂ 
it to a new spot that just makes all the edgesÂ Â

straight, let it cool a little not much just aÂ 
little so it's not quite as runny and then wrap itÂ Â

around your cake and then you want to do the exactÂ 
same thing with the little one put them in theÂ Â

fridge for 10 minutes and then peel off the foilÂ 
now you can leave it just like that or if you haveÂ Â

luster dust you can give it a gentle brush overÂ 
with some luster dust of your choice of color addÂ Â

the smaller cake back on top of the big one andÂ 
yes you can still see the indent at the bottom butÂ Â

it's not as noticeable with the crinkly chocolateÂ 
and this would be fine if you're having a party.Â Â

Cake fail number two is that sinking feeling whenÂ 
a cake comes out of the oven and it sinks down inÂ Â

the center my neighbor sent me this photo askingÂ 
if she puts the cake back in the oven will itÂ Â

go back up? She needed it for a birthday partyÂ 
... sadly the answer is no it won't go back upÂ Â

they usually sink in the middle if they're notÂ 
quite cooked enough. Cake cooking times varyÂ Â

so much depending on the oven and the type ofÂ 
dish used when you're baking it. Emeroy was bakingÂ Â

a red velvet cake that was clearly underbakedÂ 
when he took it out. Nene 78 baked these threeÂ Â

cakes and the big one ended up like this oftenÂ 
people think they can bake a cake in one largeÂ Â

tin instead of two smaller ones so let's do thatÂ 
and see what happens i've got one batch of myÂ Â

rich chocolate cake mix here and i'll tip all ofÂ 
that into a big tin now i've made up another batchÂ Â

of the exact same recipe and i'm going to splitÂ 
that between two cake pans. Pop them in the ovenÂ Â

and 35 minutes later if we take them out we'llÂ 
put a knife into the middle of this one and itÂ Â

comes out clean so that's done, always check withÂ 
a knife don't just go on the time and this is theÂ Â

same recipe same oven and it's definitely not doneÂ 
yet. Now if you check around the edges you can seeÂ Â

that it is cooked on the edges but it has to goÂ 
back in the oven because the middle is not cookedÂ Â

and using a large tin like this can oftenÂ 
mean that you overcook the edges and the topÂ Â

before the middle is ready to go so baking twoÂ 
thinner layers i prefer as the better option.Â Â

20 minutes of extra bake time so that's a lotÂ 
on top and you can see it's hot in the middleÂ Â

but it's still not ready, it takes a lotÂ 
lot longer if you put it in the bigger tinÂ Â

so it needs to go back in the oven but i'm notÂ 
going to put it back i'm going to leave it outÂ Â

so that we can watch it sink again and then weÂ 
can rescue it now there are several differentÂ Â

things you could do with this but i'm just goingÂ 
to level off the top of the cake and then pushÂ Â

a cookie cutter down into that middle sectionÂ 
and scoop out the center. You'll find it willÂ Â

be properly baked at the very bottom becauseÂ 
that was on the heat of the pan so just pushÂ Â

the cookie cutter all the way through and thenÂ 
trim a nice slice of cake from that bottom pieceÂ Â

now just flip the cake upside down and fill theÂ 
hole with m&m's and then add that disc of cake onÂ Â

top and now you can decorate your cake however youÂ 
were going to decorate it before it failed becauseÂ Â

it doesn't look like a fail anymore I'm going toÂ 
cover the whole thing with ganache and then pipeÂ Â

swirls of your ganache on top. Cake Fail numberÂ 
3 is the bucket cake or the plant pot-shapedÂ Â

cake and I'm not even sure what went wrong here iÂ 
don't know if that's melted fondant or if that'sÂ Â

buttercream and they didn't use fondant but theyÂ 
certainly didn't get to what they were going for.Â Â

Jessica called this one a fail now I actuallyÂ 
think this one's not too bad but if you're notÂ Â

happy with it here is a quick fix that you couldÂ 
do. Melt some compound white chocolate if you'veÂ Â

got some oil-based food coloring you can use thatÂ 
otherwise just leave it white tip that into aÂ Â

clean bucket or plant pot that has no holes in theÂ 
bottom this one is a brand new plant pot and i'veÂ Â

washed it to make sure it's 100 per cent cleanÂ 
and you need to make sure it's really really dryÂ Â

then you want to tip that container and swirlÂ 
the chocolate around so that it goes right toÂ Â

the very top and then tip out the excess chocolateÂ 
and put it in the fridge for a few minutes to set.Â Â

That gives us a really thin layer of chocolateÂ 
and this is just going to break if we try andÂ Â

take it out so we're just going to repeat thatÂ 
same process a couple of times just to buildÂ Â

up the layers and thicken it up especially aroundÂ 
that top lip once that's set you just pull up andÂ Â

out of the container chocolate shrinks a littleÂ 
as it sits so it makes it quite easy to get outÂ Â

now it's just a matter of stacking up the cake andÂ 
the frosting inside of this chocolate container.Â Â

This is also a great fix for many cake failsÂ 
because you can put a crumbled mess in hereÂ Â

and no one would know then put some biscuits intoÂ 
a food processor if you don't have a processor youÂ Â

can just put them in a plastic bag and squashÂ 
them with a rolling pin or a book or anythingÂ Â

that you've got that you can hit it with ğŸ ThenÂ 
put some frosting onto a cake board or a plateÂ Â

and add your cake, pile some cookie crumbs on topÂ 
of the cake now obviously if you want this to beÂ Â

a plant pot rather than a bucket of sand on theÂ 
beach then you'd be better off using oreos becauseÂ Â

they crush up and look like soil. You can put someÂ 
sand around the base too or some cookie crumbsÂ Â

obviously and then if you want a handle on yourÂ 
bucket put some chocolate on a strip of acetateÂ Â

and then just before it's set add it to the sideÂ 
of the bucket peel off the acetate and add aÂ Â

circle of blue chocolate on top where it joins onÂ 
each side and you have an impressive looking cakeÂ Â

rescue! Okay one more there were so many photos ofÂ 
failed bunt cakes including this one that was forÂ Â

a first birthday party the trouble with bundt cakeÂ 
tins is that you can't line them with non-stickÂ Â

paper because of their uneven sort of grooves andÂ 
the grooves also give the cake something to stickÂ Â

to i'm going to generously spray one half of thisÂ 
tin with oil and leave the other half ungreasedÂ Â

then add in my lemon and blueberry cake mixtureÂ 
and bake that the edge of the side that had oilÂ Â

looks different to the side without on the oilÂ 
side you can also see if i shake it it is looseÂ Â

and then if i turn that you can see this side isÂ 
stuck in the pan it's not lifting when i shake itÂ Â

so what i'd suggest you do at this stage is youÂ 
get a knife or a spoon and loosen it around theÂ Â

edge wherever it is stuck until when youÂ 
shake it it's loose the whole way aroundÂ Â

but i'm not going to do that because i wantÂ 
it to break so i'm just going to tip it out...

oh nuts ğŸ¥œ it turned out perfectly it's very hardÂ 
to get a fail when you want it to fail! I'm justÂ Â

going gonna have to rip it apart that looks moreÂ 
like it now you could just eat this of course it'sÂ Â

cake and it tastes good but if you are having aÂ 
party and you want it to be more presentable hereÂ Â

is a fix for you grab some yogurt in whateverÂ 
flavor you like and some cream and some gelatinÂ Â

and i'll put these recipe quantities on my websiteÂ 
for you take a third of a cup of that cream andÂ Â

stir it into the gelatin straight away then grabÂ 
a third of a cup of the yogurt and stir that in asÂ Â

well whip the rest of the cream until you get softÂ 
peaks now put the softened gelatin mixture intoÂ Â

the microwave to melt it you want to stir thatÂ 
until you can no longer see any lumps of gelatinÂ Â

now if you want it sweeter or if your yogurt isn'tÂ 
sweet add some more sugar into this hot gelatinÂ Â

mixture and stir it till it's dissolved i'm notÂ 
adding extra sugar to mine but you can to yoursÂ Â

now stir that in with the yogurt and once that'sÂ 
all combined then pour that into the whipped creamÂ Â

and fold them together and you've made a simpleÂ 
yogurt mousse scoop that into the bundt panÂ Â

and put it all the way up and aroundÂ 
the edges then add your chunks of cakeÂ Â

into the pan add more and more cake and mousseÂ 
until you're filled right up to the top and thenÂ Â

we're going to put this in the freezer now thatÂ 
it's frozen you've got the problem of getting itÂ Â

out of the tin again of course to do that put theÂ 
tin in a sink of warm water and make sure that itÂ Â

doesn't go over the top of course you just want itÂ 
around the edges. Then you'll need to poke a knifeÂ Â

down one side to let some air out otherwiseÂ 
you've got a vacuum and it won't come outÂ Â

and then it should just pop out of the tin andÂ 
you can center that on your plate now you couldÂ Â

glaze this but i'm going to keep it simple andÂ 
just use a hot spoon to smooth out those bitsÂ Â

of mousse that we melted by putting the tin inÂ 
warm water leave it to defrost in the fridgeÂ Â

and then serve it up at your party. With thanksÂ 
to my wonderful patrons for your amazing support.Â Â

If you like Cake Rescues let the algorithm knowÂ
